editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Arcadia
Arcadia.
Arcadia.

Sidney, Philip, 1554-1586.

div.p: Acted by her majesty's servants at the phoenix in Drury lane.
London, printed by I. D. for John Williams, and F. Eglesfeild and are to be sold at the sign of the crane in Paul's churchyard. 1640.

list.head: The persons of the comedy.
list.item: Musidorus a prince disguised as a shepherd, lover of Pamela,
Pyrocles a prince disguised as an Amazon, lover of Philoclea.
Dametas a rustic shepherd and guardian to Pamela and
Thumb a miller captain of the rebels.
Mopsa daughter to Dametas and Miso.

div.head: Actus primus.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Sir yet be gracious and hear them pray
That beg not for their own, but for your safety
And honour of your state which eclipse
In your long dark and melancholy life,
We want you at the helm.
Our duties bind us tell you 'tis unnatural
To bury yourself alive, the people call
For their own King to govern, they'll forget
To pray for you if you continue thus
A stranger to 'em

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Or if not for them
Which every good King makes his care as being
A steward to provide them all earthly blessings,
yet for the other part of you, our mistress
That sleeps within your bosom, and not made
For such a conversation, return
And warm your thoughts again, about which all
Your servants like so many pictures gaze
At one another, but want motion, and take up
Room ith' chambers of your court, like arras

sp.speaker: Philon
sp.l: Have a compassion to our daughter's sir
Kill not your hopes in their restraint

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: What cage
Can please the birds created for sky freedom?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: How can you see your eldest child Pamela
Spend her best part of time with such a rude
And ignorant hind as the unbred Dametas?
A lady of a high and active soul,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: No more

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Our duties bids us tell you this.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Hast thou forgotten
Philonax, or made a better gloss upon the oracle?
Should we remain in court and let our daughters
Be in the sight of the admiring world
Read that paper, and be not partial Philonax

quote.l: Thy eldest care shall from thy careful face
By princely mean be stolen and yet not lost
The younger shall with nature's bliss embrace
An uncouth love, which nature hateth most
Both these themselves unto two such shall wed
That at a beer, as at a bar shall plead
Why I'll thee a living man they have made dead,
In thine own seat a foreign state shall sit
And ere that all these blows thy head shall sit
Thou with thy wife adultery shall commit.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Canst blame me now? I should rejoice to see
My daughter's happy mothers, but since their
Fate must be ripened with my blood, their pride
Rooted in my grave, and that untimely, 'tis
wisdom to keep 'em virgins. I me resolved

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Your Queen and ladies

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Vanish all discontent, madam this place
Is empty of all royal entertainment
Your worth may challenge, but since fate allows not
A courtly life which best may answer your
High birth spirit, let your virtue guide you
To accept of what we tender,

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: This my lord
Exceeds all merit here, it was the bliss
I aimed at to be acquainted with your goodness
I am your humble servant

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Such a title
Would rather become me, call me so lady
And style me above Kings, while I write yours

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: If your grace
Could call him from this life you'd melt the hearts
Of your subjects into prayers for you

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.l: I thank your care but he's inexorable

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: Alas dear Princess can you brook these grove:
Has not a palace something more of pleasure?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This shall be so to me while 'tis my fathers,

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I ha' not seen a goodlier person, how
Came she admitted ▪ 〈◊〉 gracious with the King

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She has a charm to win from all the world

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: I have read the Amazons described so

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Good my lord.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: These lips had he that robbed the dragon of
The golden apples, but once seen he would
Ha wished to ha' gathered fruit here, and esteemed
The gain of one sweet kiss reward sufficient
For all his twelve hard labours

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Sir your grace
Is pleasantly disposed to make my person
The subject of your mirth

sp.speaker: Bas
sp.l: And had those creatures,
Book blinded men, that dream of other worlds
tell of Elysian blessings, know the joys
Are in your love they would have lost themselves
As I have done in speculation

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You make me blush to hear you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: There's no action
Dares so affright your blood, to talk, why lady
There be those men and women great and good
Have found no shame in telling of their loves
Nay in the acting

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Give me leave to tell you
You are not modest if I understand you
A King give breath to such foul thoughts,
Your every action should be a star
To guide your subjects, if you lose your piety
What wickedness have they not hence for
If the devotion of your service be
To such a friend as lust (As what name else
Can it deserve) let those whose hearts are lost
In sin be tempted to dishonour, I
Abhor the thought, pardon me royal sir
I hope these are but trials, if I thought
There had been such a levity in men
Thus to provoke you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Smooth thy brow again
Or I shall need no other punishment
There's death too much in that; Philocles

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: That name sounds all my comfort, and I must
Despair to tell her so, I was to blame
To be so peremptory, would I were again;
To shape my answer

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Noble lady.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Sir

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: That smile has put me out, o look thus ever
I was studying a new compliment to beg
Thy excuse

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: If you brought no offence there needs none sir
I must suppose your love, love is noble chaste

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: You will find that hereafter, o Zelmane.
Would thou couldst tell the meaning of my sighs

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You can express them.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Not I

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Choose another to speak them for you
And yet I want an or at or to tell you
What I would say, howe'er I seem

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Dost bless me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: There's something wants a tongue, but for your passions
I should not think they would carry so much discord
To any virgin care delivered by a woman
There is a way to meet a gentle audience.
At least not harsh disdain, did your fair daughter
Philoclea the volume of all sweetness
Plead half your suit, although it bordered on
Something not altogether just, her tongue
Might perchance guide it, but I am confident
Your ends are noble

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: There's a lightning yet
Of comfort, happiest lady I will study.
How to be worthy of this grace,

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.l: You are expected at the pastorals

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: We take our leaves my lord again beseeching
Your pardon for our boldness to reduce you
To your own sphere of greatness

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Do you continue
Faithful to your employments, and deserve of us
And of your country; come Zelmane
There are some sports which you must grace

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I wait a servant to your commands

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Come sweet Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Come sweetest of thy sex

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: 'Tis pity nature.
Made thee not a man, this compliment
Would then become you

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Mopsa you are too coy in my opinion
Though I confess your beauty may deserve
As much as any; Dorus though he be
your father's servant, he's a handsome shepherd
And not to be despised.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Despised, cannot a virgin love a young man I pray but she must despise him.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You should then with some smiles encourage him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Smoyles, let me alone to smile, and something else when we are alone; if I thought he did not love me, I know what I know

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Alas poor man he cannot sleep for you he says,

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay and I were a-bed with him he should not sleep so long as his eyes were open, I'd watch him for that, but do you think my father would let us couple in matrimony as they say, he has never a son but I and I am his only daughter.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Make no scruple of that, if you can find in your heart to love him, in the name of Cupid go together, for ought I perceive your father holds a good opinion of him, marry I know not how your mother is inclined

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Whoop my mother's a scold

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Here's your sweet heart ▪
Look you make much of him, poor gentleman
How love is able to transport, who could
Expect so rich a guest in that poor dwelling
O howe'er the winds compel him, or the stream
Into whose troubled waves he has launched forth
This way he steers his love, yet I seem ignorant.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: My dearest Mopsa

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Dear; I never cost you anything

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I know not
At what expense of fortunes were I able
I should be willing to make purchase of you
But I'm sure you have already cost my heart
And yet I find yours made of marble
Which neither pity nor my prayers can soften,
Sweet madam plead for me, one gracious word
From you would make me happy, let one beam
Shoot from your eye, and it will strike a spring
Into that frozen piece of earth, and make it
A bower for love to sport in, 'tis in you
to unarm her noble heart, there's too much steel
And gentle love in vain attempts to fasten
The softer blows.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Mopsa take heed, your shepherd can speak well
And if he be honest Menalcus' brother
And heir, I know no reason why you should
Think scorn of him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: But for all his quaint speeches I'll keep my honesty
Close enough I warrant you

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Why should you be so cruel, nature made
Your face the only object of man's wonder

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Does my face look like a flapjack?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Is't possible there can be a soul so hard
So unrelenting dwell in that fair body?
If you knew the truth of my affection and with what
Religion it looks upon your virtues.
'T would teach your eye compassion, gracious Princess
Let the distressed Dorus gain this mercy
From you that with the blessedness of your
White hand reaching to Mopsa this poor toy
Which late I found my love may cherish hope
At last to be accepted

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: O fine what's that madam?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: You must yet be a little coy to receive it

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: I wonot have it, and he would give it me

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: A rich jewel the figure of a crabfish

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: The true emblem of my love's pace which looks another way
To that it moves, she cannot but distinguish
Whether I would direct my heart, her eyes
Are fixed upon't, and my poor soul could here
Star-gaze for ever

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: By force not choice — all his desire is Mopsa
Tow in your grace by my presenting it

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: I'll take it for your sake, I wonot thank him

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: She has no apprehension, with what
A calm and careless temper does she give it

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: Madam Pamela, o are you there, 'tis well

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.l: I me out of breath, let me walk myself a little

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What haste does tire you?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Tire me, I am no woman, keep your tires to yourself
Nor am I Pericles' prince of tire.

sp.speaker: Pam
sp.l: I do believe it, heaven make you an honest subject,
For a wise one, I despair to see you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Am I the subject of your talk? But I give you leave to use your tongue, you're a woman, Dorus what make you idling here? is the field dunged as I gave directions, and the calf with the white face brought home to execution?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I was careful in my duty.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Believe me governor there is much hope of your servant,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ay, governor becomes you, I like it well when you carry an m under your girdle, our govern, he will do pretty well in time, when I have taught him the manners of the cart, he begins whistle in tune already, and can curry favour with the horses, but now I remember myself I forgotten what I came hither for, o d'ye hear 'tis the King your father's pleasure and mine, that you make haste to the lodge.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I'll attend

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: There will be gambols to please my lady Salamandor.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Zelmane you would say.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I care not what you say, but if you mean to hear the dances and see the fine songs you must make haste; Dorus you shall have leave to shake your heels, look you be mannerly, and show a clean calf, Mopsa what's that you ha' got there?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: A fine thing our man Dorus game, he says 'tis a fish

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: 'Tis a cod's head is't not, much came how you by this

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Following the plow I found it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Would all my acres were sown with such, umh doors he throw his stones at thee already, well set forward, if thou diest before me Dorus I'll make somebody mine heir; if I out live thee, I wonot say what legacy I mean to bestow upon thee, continue thy duty Dorus and follow me with a reverence.

div.stage: Enter Basilius, Gynoecia, Pyrocles, Pamela, Philoclea, Mopsa, Musidorus, a shepherd's.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Ladies our revels wants the state and glory
with which the court delights might charm your senses
Our scene is natural but interpret fairly 'twas meant
A cure for times sick feathers, and your mirth,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Virtue will prompt you to
Accept what was intended for your service
Yet 'tis within my wishes to salute you
With other testimony of your welcome.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I kiss your white hand,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Every touch conveys a fierce spirit through my blood
I shall betray my suffering, and through my eyes
Let out my heart, Philoclea sit

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Will't please you rest yourself?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Dwell here for ever
I am now but one degree from heaven,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Since you imagine you are so near, it is no sin
I hope to entreat you stay with us a little, I would
Wish though to make you blessed with too hasty a remove ▪

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You are all goodness, o that I durst but give
Some liberty to my imprisoned thoughts

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Philoclea you hinder the fair stranger.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Pardon me that am her trouble rather

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: She should want virtue to call you so, but they begin
Dametas is the steward for this day's mirth I see.
And means to bring in the first course.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Cupid is blind some say but there are lies
Abroad, for Cupid never wanted eyes
He is a deity with bow and arrow
And he can pierce with it the very marrow
And never hurt the bones, is't not a wonder.
That flaming ice should cut man's heart in sunder,
sp.stage: Enter Cupid shepherd musedo. Mopsa and Miso:
sp.l: Behold the dandiprat that lived at court.
But is come hither to make country sport
A woody god; but yet a very colt
Among the maids who feel his furious boult.
Now Cupid speak thyself or while they play
Sing if you please I ha' not more to say.
Cupid. Tell me tidings of my mother.
Shepherds, and be Cupid's brother
Down from heaven we came together
With swans speed came she not hither?
But what lady have I spied.
Just so was my mother eyed
Such her smiles wherein I dwelled
In those lips have I been felt
Those the pillows of her breast
Which gave Cupid so much rest.
'Tis she 'tis she make holiday
Shepherds carol dance and play
'Tis Venus it can be no other
Cupid now has found his mother

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: This was your poetry, Zelmane
You are beholding to him, he would make
You another I see,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Gynoecia

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: I am silent — Philoclea is too near
I am not well oth' sudden, break off your mirth

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: What ails Gynoecia?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: My heart is sick

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Forbid it heaven

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Retire, come my Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I attend

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Look to your charge Dametas

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I have a precious time; will you pace it governor?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Trot, amble or gallop I'll run in your hand lady.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Come Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Your humble servant

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Thou art cruel.
To an innocent bosom love, there is no way
Within thy power to save me, o Philoclea
Where shall I cool my heart, o if there be
One shaft can kill, good Cupid aim at me.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I warrant you madam they shall have good luck if they whisper together in my hearing,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Where is Zelmane?

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: In some of the arbours, she took a lute abroad with her but I left Philoclea with her father

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Prithee be careful and watch them well good Miso

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: They sha'not scape me, I'll watch their waters narrowly I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: I see through his disguise 'tis so, and love
Hath put this shape on him for Philoclea,
In what a miserable flame I burn!
Zelmane thou hast stolen.
My virtue from me, I ha' not power to think
A harmless thought, ha music,
sp.stage: Music. Song Pyrocles sings enter Pyroclos.
sp.l: From whence breathes that sound? it is Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: What miserable accident brought her?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Madam I hope you'll pardon
The trespass of a rude hand and voice, I meant not
This for your curious care

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: 'Twas harmony

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: It was no light air I'm sure

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Indeed it carried something methought
Of sorrow's descant, I heard love in't too
Who is so happy to deserve a memory
But in your sigh, come who's your servant?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I have no servant.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Nay then I see you can dissemble, my husband

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Madam I hope

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Nay I am so far from jealousy I should not
Be angry to see you both a-bed together

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: How madam

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Why I can love you too, come thou shalt be my bedfellow

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I am not worthy

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Believe me I could take as much delight
In thy embraces as my husbands, why
Are we so nice to one another, I
Am a woman, are not you so too?
Why should we not be bold then, I have a mind
To call thee mistress, yes and I'll disguise.
Myself in some quaint shape to court thy love:

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Disguise

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Nay do not blush: thou shalt be a man

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Your discourse appears.
Strange to me madam.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: As you would to me
And yet you may as easily perceive
Gynoecia's mind as I distinguish you
Through all your clouds, Cupid doth dictate rarely.
To those that come to school to him, instruct
With handsome shadows to deceive the eye
But cannot change my substance, I have a sense
Can look beyond the superficial bark
Come you're transparent

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Madam what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: What means Zelmane to be ignorant
When a Queen pleads for love, my heart will not
Allow more circumstance; do not question
How you became revealed, but pity her
Whose bosom is tormented with those fires
Thy smiles the only greater flame can quench.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Pray heaven, you have your perfect senses.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Then I must be plainer, and be witness love
I am compelled, be witness modesty,
I now must blush for thee more than myself,
A man, and be so cruel to a lady
Zelmane either give consent I shall
Be welcome to thee, or I vow by heaven
To tell Basilius what thou art, I have
Patience to let him court thee as a woman
But when he see's his love abuse his privacy
and daughters so dishonoured hadst thou a thousand
Lives they were all forfeited by this
So desperate intrusion , think upon't
A woman I have lost thee, whither will
The tempest of my fate enforce my tongue
Yet be thou kind Zelmane if thou takest
A glory in my suffering, Philoclea
Does that name startle you? Philoclea
My rival now

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Your rival

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Come I am familiar with every thought
Your dear saint shall repent it, for this hand
Shall take again the unlucky life I gave her:
Turn not Gynoecia fury

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I am lost
In the same minute I am found, I prithee
Do not forsake me heart, I never had
More use of thee, great Queen can you forgive?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: And ask thy pardon, but believe me was
Your strangeness did compel me to this language

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: I never thought that pity of another
Could be a reason to betray myself
But you have thoroughly charmed me, and I must
Deliver up my thoughts, the truth is madam
I am a man, and if you dare believe me
A prince, I must confess beside Gynoecia
Since I came hither I have had some sprinkling of
I know not what affection to Philoclea
For how could I imagine such a blessedness
From you, but if you mock not

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Joys reward your pity
O pardon the over charged Gynoecia
Whose error may be yet made more excusable
By the immortal name of love

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: This grace is worth more than Zelmane, and yet I
Have nothing but myself to give you for it
A small but free gift, bestow me as you please

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: My soul is narrow to receive this wide blessing.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: But me must be wise
It were not safe to be observed stand I
Discovered to none else?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: To none

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Then know
I want no apprehension of what
True lovers would desire, but your honour is
My own, if shortly to secure 'em both
You let me study an opportunity
I'll bring your wishes home, and bless my stars
That pointed me the glorious fate, we are
Already interrupted

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Do this my dear Philoclea, and leave
My cares to thee, I'll call Gynoecia
Away, and leave you both together, how
Fareth the best Zelmane?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Still your servant

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Gynoecia.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I cannot rule my eyes they will betray
My cunning to Gynoecia if she go not
Hence quickly

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How is it with my virtuous Amazon?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Philoclea

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Let her alone, they have some business sweet

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: What business can they have together?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Why art thou troubled, thou wouldst be jealous
Of me I see, were I in private with her,
Come let 'em alone a while

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Stay you and spare not I would employ Philoclea

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: You shall obey me now, I prithee walk

sp.speaker: Phi,
sp.l: My father sweet Zelmane to whose command
I owe my life

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: First let me give my life
Up to these lips, and take a new one from
This kiss, o dear Philoclea contain
All other breath I know thy father's mind
Already, and must now beseech thy patience
to a short story which I must deliver
Or die before thee, if it be within
My destiny to be condemned by you
At least know whom you sentence; I am

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What? I fear not well

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Cannot your eyes discover me, have I a shroud
To hide me from Philoclea? did the kiss
I gave thee last convey no secret to thee?
There was a spirit in my lip assured me.
To save the tedious trouble of my language.
I heard it whisper something, did it not?
I would be fain undone

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Good heaven forbid

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You wonot understand me yet Philoclea
Then I'll undo myself, I am not what
I seem Zelmane; but —

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: P●.
sp.l: A thing not worth the name, if you frown on me, a man

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: A man, good heaven—

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I have told you all the worst
If it be no offence to name a prince
Whose memory your own breath oft hath sweetened
I dare be called Pyrocles of Macedon
Transformed by loving your fair self to this
Feminine shape, if now I have not sinned
Above forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O Philoclea
Come not too near I charge you; I would chide.
But dare not, would you had not told me this
Indeed you were to blame, I must not hear you
Excuse yourself

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: She must not leave me thus
But she returns

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have lost myself already,
And love is but a blind guide to direct
My virgin steps, I fain would reply something
But feel a trembling in my voice, Zelmane
My father, what account shall I give him
I have said nothing he commanded

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: She smiles

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: My lord I see you can use the advantage
And I did arm you against myself; I did not
Think when I advised you make Philoclea
Your advocate, she could so much have won
Upon me, but my counsel has betrayed me,
Pray think me not immodest, if my words
Do fall too rudely from me, your fair daughter
Whose tongue would lay a charm upon the gods,
Hath gained all this.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: The gods reward her for it

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Was this his plot?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: A thousand blessings overtake my child
But not a word, not a word Philoclea
To thy mother

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I have learned my duty sir

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Beshrew your haste

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Remove, convey thyself away dear girl, I'll follow

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My heart is full, and though my tongue denies
Him farewell, he may read it in my eye.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I knew thou couldst not choose at last but give
My heart an audience; I am not myself
With the imagination

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Of any thing; come I allow thee modest, it is not fit we should say our pleasures, sweet but act them

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You are too violent my lord, I shall
Repent my freedom, if you give no limit
To your desires, if you do love your servant,
Husband your flame that it may last

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: It shall
Pardon me dear Zelmane, I have a stock
Of blood, though you may think it could is high
And active as the veins of promising youth
I wear this snow but a disguise

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Poor winter,

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: My hairs are black at root, and shall grow up
fair as the ebony and curl themselves
Into a thousand pretty caves for love
Itself to sit that best delights in darkness

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: This will be strange.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: 'Tis you that work these miracles
Upon Basilius, as I came hither
I felt a score of years drop off, which hung
Upon my locks

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: A score of hairs you mean: 'tis molting time
Contain yourself a while, you have
A jealous Queen, and yet it goes against my conscience
To wrong so sweet a lady, pray my lord
Think better on't

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: This does inflame me more
Be not so cruel to remember her
Thou must preserve my life.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Well I ha' thought a way
Shall perfect all without suspicion
There is a cave hard by which nature made
Intending well to lovers, thither will I
With licence of your grace pretending
To exercise a few days some devotions
We Amazons have obligation to
At some convenient hour.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: May I come to thee

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I'll give you notice in some evening

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Zelmane now thou dost ravish me

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: You may with ease secure all at the lodge

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Most excellent

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I imagine sir the rest but do not come till I desire you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Be not tedious then, I will prepare all this

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I hope you do not
Conclude me impudent that I incline
To do this for you, by my hopes of a blessed
Eternity nor love nor lust ere tempted
My thoughts to yield thus much to any man
Be careful of my honour.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O divine Zelmane keep my soul.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Philoclea mine

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: O my dear Pyrocles

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: How is't dear cousin

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Never till now could you salute me happy
The gods have been propitious

sp.speaker: Pyr,
sp.l: Will she know thee yet?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: There's nothing wants to make me perfect blessed
But to hear thee pronounce thy love as fortunate
The envious clouds which interpose themselves
Like a dark curtain o'er Pamela's face.
Are drawn away and I enjoy her smile
She does believe my proofs, sweetly excusing
Her long neglect, and promiseth as much
As I dare ask: she'll 'Trust me with her person
I want but opportunity to deceive
Our waking dragons; — and in good time Dametas.
Away you shall know all my fate hereafter,

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I joy in thy success, pray thou for mine.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Where is this rascal Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Whether were I best to tell the King on't first or seek out
Dametas, he'll never be able to spend it, there may be gold
Enough to purchase half Arcadia

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Umh, what's that?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I'll seek him out at all adventures; o sir, pray is this
Gold — and this and this?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ha gold, yes very good gold, where hadst it

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: You shall hear more hereafter

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Dorus, honest Dorus, put on thy hat, where where, hadst it

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Did you never hear of one Aristomines?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: He was banished Arcadia

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Was he rich

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Infinite rich, so rich

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: 'Tis so, belike he there had all his treasure

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: What treasure, where is't honest Dorus tell me

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: You are my master and may be my father

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: My son Dorus, Mopsa is thine, and she were made of as pure gold as this, thou shouldst touch her, and melt her

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Well I see it was ordained to make you rich
in duty I'll discover it, and yet —

sp.speaker: Drm.
sp.l: Out with it good Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Well — sitting beneath an oak that shall be nameless
I chanced to turn up some turf with my mole-spade

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: With thy mole spade, what then

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I saw a yellow brightness peeping out oth' ground, which
When I came to examine I proved this mettle, I this was the first,
You're sure 'tis gold, you shall pardon me for the rest but if these
Will do you any pleasure, or twenty more

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Nay good honest Dorus proceed.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Why the truth is I suspect where a great treasure has been
Long buried, these it seems were scattered when the rest
Went to the pit-hole.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: But where is this place good Dorus? thou hast no more
About thee

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: No but if you please to furnish me with tools I'll try
The bottom; I digged till I came to a stone, whose inscription
Promised something worth a man's labour

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Did it sound

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Melodiously a golden tune

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Where, where, thou mayst tell me thou knowest I
Am secret

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: For Mopsa sake I will reveal't, you know ▪
The oak where you first met me

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ha very well

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: On the right side of that same spreading tree
Lies all this riches

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: As thou'rt honest

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: As I hope to be dear Mopsa's husband, I'll get strong tools
And bring you better proof

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Stay Dorus stay, let me see
As I intend to be your father Dorus
And so in Mopsa's name make you my heir
Of all my wealth, good Dorus I am yet
Till things and things be done your master Dorus
Beside that ground is mine, the oak is mine
Where under lies this treasure, I am lord
Lord of the soil my Dorus, of the soil
I am content to be a ground for you
To build to hopes on Dorus, but my ground
No man shall dig or build on but myself
On such as this, be there a mine
Of coin or uncoin mettle it is mine
All may be yours another day my Dorus.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I know my duty sir and cannot think
The gods had ere a lotted my free mind
To serve you but for some strange end

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: In this thou showst it, keep all close, not a word Dorus, I take no leave be careful my good Dorus of my young madam, 'tis a charge I turn over to thee, over look her well.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I mean to do it doubly

sp.speaker: Dam
sp.l: How, ha' you a double meaning?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I mean with double care

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Honest Dorus 'tis the last service I shall put thee to

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I hope so to

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Now to the oak my golden land mark

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Load a horse with tools sir

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Mattocks and shovels

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hooks and ladders.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Spade and pickaxes

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Ropes and daggers; you'll have no help

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: No no, a man's own toil
Sweeter the profit makes in his own soil.

sp.speaker: Mus
sp.l: Go thy ways for the lord a'th soil
There's one block out a'th way the golden fly,
Has caught this trout, my jealous mistress I
Hope she o'er heard not

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: O that my ears had been long enough to have heard some of there precious knavery

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: It were but charity to tell her on't, little does my mistress think what a flesh fly my master is,

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: What says the knave

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Though she be a little stricken in years she is handsome enough
For as good a man as Dametas, and he to run neighing
A this fashion after a blowse, and then put me to make excuse
for him, 'tis not right.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.l: O fidious rascal, I thought there was some roguery,
Dorus as thou comest of a woman tell me

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: What forsooth

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: O naughty man to use an honest woman the wrong way thus, have I been married so many years, and carried myself like his lawful wife uprising and down lying as they say, so even and jump with his desires to be thus handled, but I'll be revenged it shall fall heavy upon his head for this I warrant him, nay I did always suspect him for a co●t

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What mean you forsooth,

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Come I overheard somewhat to my grief, and therefore leave your boggling and your trim tram tricks you must not flap me o'th' mouth with fleering and with flams whilst he

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Claps up another betwixt the — a ha mistress mistress but you say you overheard, and therefore if you know whether he is gone you may come two hours hence time enough to prevent the blow.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: If thou lookest to have my daughter with, mark what I say

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: With father's mark and mother's mark, and every mark about her

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: If you conceal any thing in this case, thou knowest no case of her, nay though thy teeth water out the liquor of thy life, thou shouldst not get a bit, the worst bit of her.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Be more charitable

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Or if thou chance to get her 'gainst my will I'll teach her a trick of the mother shall make thee curse her and all the brood she came one,

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What is Charita to me, I know you heard him name her.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Charita.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I will discharge my conscience and yet if you overheard us without my telling, you know where he appointed to meet her this evening at Mantinea at her fathers in Ondemion street,

sp.speaker: Mis
sp.p: Ondemion street?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I do not betray him now if you provide so happily to take 'em at it mistress at it.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: I at it, how I itch to be at it

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Saddle your mare.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: They shall not scape with half an eye betwixt them.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I have given her the bells and she will fly to the devil — here comes the tother I ha' given her physic already fit for her constitution and now it works.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: How comes it Mopsa that you are so taken
So lifted up with high conceit?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Who I

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Yes Mapsa you, d'ye think I cannot judge
By outward gestures and your looks what joy
Doth inwardly possess you

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Who me

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Yes you again, and it were not over boldness
To request some knowledge of the cause

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Rest you content; you are a Princess born I might have been so to, somebody may be a Queen before you, make what you can of that

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: O fate how's this

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: There is a tree, and there is things worth wishing, and some may wish and wishes may be had make what you can of that too

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: To my wish it works

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: But Mopsa may I not beseech a word
That may be to my understanding

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: You may know more hereafter, but till then I must presume upon your princely patience to keep your chamber, it is now my reign and do not dare to follow

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Not I, when you are drawn up to majesty
I can but wish you graciously would then
Remember the obedience of your handmaid
That first submits herself to your command.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: i'faith I will Pamela, and reward it, go in sweet lady, on my royal word I will,

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: She has spied me

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Happy Dorus

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: What will my Mopsa say when she has climbed
the tree of happiness?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I I the tree, when I climb that tree, honey Dorus tell me it over again, my dear bird what did Jupiter to Apollo.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Upon some falling out I told you Jupiter threw Apollo out of heaven and his deity taken away he was fain to live upon the earth and keep Admetus cattle, in the time of his service being sent to fetch a breed of beasts out of Arcadia, in this very desert he grew faint and weary; and would needs rest himself in the boughs of an ashen tree.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: The tree we wot of; on sweet bird

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Apollo in that tree calling to mind his quarrel with Jupiter became very sorrowful, and pitifully complaining to his father, asking him mercy for having offended him was from that tree received into his golden sphere, and made a god again

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: O brave

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Having the perfect nature of a god
Never to be ingrateful he then granted
A double life to Admetus', and because
That tree was chapel of his happy prayers
To it he gave this quality

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Now it comes

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: That whosoever sat down in that tree
In like estate and sort as he did then

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: O now now now.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Should forthwith have there their wish

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: O the tree, the tree, the tree

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: The King understood thus much by oracle; and tried himself but being neither herdsman as then Apollo was, nor of the race which is necessary, delivered this secret to your father but made him swear to wish by his direction; for his own benefit Dametas told it me, and is now gone to furnish himself with a scarlet cloak for in that he must be muffled just as Apollo was, I might now prevent 'em all and be King myself, but what have I to wish more than the love of Mopsa which since without more charming force you yield me; I'll fit you with a cloak and then wish what you will yourself

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
I'll be Queen or Apollo shall never look me in the face again, quickly sweet Dorus, come muffle me I long to be Queen,
and my father shall ask me blessing.

div.head: Actus tertius.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come my masters let us be resolute, is there any man that will justify himself to be sober amongst us?
No hang sobriety

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: We must be valiant, the King I say again has left us, and since he scorns our company for my part I scorn to be his subject
I I scorn subjects, I'll be an emperor
It is time to look into the government, none but gentlemen are of his counsel, I see no reason since the country is 'Ours but we should have a stroke in the state.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: That was bravely spoke my bully, stroke, he by Mars his gauntlet spoke like a soldier, I do not like the carriage of the secret counsels
Nor I nor anybody

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: Take heed my masters
Let's hear Thumb the miller

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: We met together to drink in honour of the King's birthday and though we have tickled the cannikins, let us be merry and wise that's my opinion, no treason, the King is an honest gentleman, and so is the Queen.
Very wisely spoken.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But shall be governed by Philonax ':
Who knows but he has made away the King

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Made away the King, who honest Basilius, ask the King who has made him away, by this hand if I thought they had made him away I would make somebody away, though I hanged fort, but neighbours for my own part I will join with you in any thing that is honourable, d'ye mark honourable; but I say still I am clear of opinion it is not a miss to be merry and wise gentlemen, my name's Thumb,
I Tom

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: And I'll be a your side howsoever
A great spirit

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Shall I speak for you

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: I I agreed you shall be captain

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why then let me alone; I will know a reason why he has left the government without our consents to depose him, 'tis wisely spoken my brave men oth' commonwealth, we will have other laws and the old shall be executed
I I hang the old ones
'Tis a discredit for any subjects as we are to have a King as if we were not able to govern ourselves

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Stroke up thy forehead thou wert born to be a statesman, be ruled by me and we'll have no justice in Arcadia
How

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No justice, why should we lose our liberties, and being free men, upon any occasion suffer ourselves to be bound over

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Gentlemen citizens it were very good you would take into your consideration the statute against drunkenness

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It shall be lawful for any man to be drunk without forfeiting or paying anything to the poor

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Very good, every man drink away his estate, and then charity begins at home,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No man shall marry
That's worse than the statute against two wives

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: For every woman shall be common
Every woman common, what shall we do withal the proper women in Arcadia

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: They shall be common too
Oh'rare, and what shall we do withal the prisons

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Set 'em a fire 'twill warm the city when there is cold doings
What with the prisoners

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Put 'em in possession of their creditors lands, they are the only men fit for authority; for no men are used worst, and they will know the better to domineer, nay we'll have admirable laws, but who shall be this ambassador to the King
Me me choose me captain,

sp.speaker: Th'
sp.p: Choose you captain, haberdasher of small wares, choose you a capon, I'll be the ambassador, ever while you live let a bold man be ambassador, and one that has a brain, I will not be meal mouthed.
Well said miller

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And because we will be wise

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I I be merry and wise, ever while you live be sober and discreet.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Say we attend here to do our duties
Duties o base

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Say so we must, he'll not come forth else
What if I could his highness there was a dance to be presented we are furnished with our noise still

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I ay, I do love this noise withal my heart

Excellent, get you behind the trees with your instruments, and tune 'em ready, the new frisk we danced at Enispies today will serve rarely as the prologue, away; but captain what shall we do with the King's daughters

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll have one

sp.l: And I'll ha' the tother our captain shall ha' the Queen

sp.p: And what shall we have.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: There are ladies about the court will content you

sp.speaker: Thu.
sp.p: I will have both the Kings daughters, and he that speaks against it —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Thumb valiant Thumb, all spirit no mutiny no mutiny all of a faction together by the ears for a piece of venison

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I will have both the Kings daughters or else I shall not be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: First let us know the King's resolution, and if we like not our conditions, the hares a foot; and every man take what course he please in my lord's parkEnter Basilius, Gynoecia, Pyrocles, and Philoclea.but stay the King umh
Speak captain

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: If it please your majesty, what was it resolved upon
He's out, let me come to him, prithee do thou tell him thy mind, that delicome wench has made my teeth water

And drowned thy tongue, a company of bashful shrimps;
if I but open my mouth, I say no more

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: King, by your leave; which is the King, my eyes twinkle, we have been playing the good fellows to celebrate your majestical birth day, will your grace see a song
A dance

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: Or a dance, all's one, our feet are in tune, strike up behind the tree, you are the King and I am the miller, there's all the difference, sweet ladies my name is Thumb

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: This is rudeness

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Pardon their simplicity

sp.speaker: Th.
sp.p: I'll have that wench she looks like Hercules, omnes, stand

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: We have intorrogations points to put to you

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Treason, treason,

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Barbarous villains

div.stage: Basilius runs in, a bell rings, Philoclea, and Gynoecia hide themselves, Pyrocles fights with them, Basilius comes in with a two handed sword, after some skirmish enter Philonax and Calandre with a guard the rebels beaten off.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Where is Philoclea

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here art thou not hurt Zelmane.
My soul at every stroke made against thee
Was leaving my pale body

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Dear madam are you safe

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: I think I ha' peppered some of 'em, Philonax 'twas not amiss you came, but Zelmane and I should have made a shift

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: You alone my lord, were an army against such reeling valours, I did not think you could ha' bestirred yourself so well

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: And I were in another place alone with thee I could bestir myself better

sp.speaker: Cal.
sp.l: I would you would consider yet to quit
This dangerous kind of life

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Had not the valiant Amazon it seems, defenced your person
Ere the troops arrived, it might have proved too fatal

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: He played the man indeed, the King is troubled
And thinks me jealous of him, lass old man

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: No more
Wait upon our Queen and daughter, we'll follow
I am wounded

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: How

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: By thee Zelmane

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I see your passions are the same and I
This might resolve to wait for you in the cave
If you when your Gynoecia is a-bed
And fast asleep , (Be sure of that) will please
To put yourself to a short travel, I
Shall not express your welcome, but

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Dear as my soul I apprehend my comfort
One kiss in earnest of the million
Thou shalt receive, but carry it close Zelmane

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: This is the tree

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: O let me kiss it toes

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Best lose no time

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Haile upon hail sweet tree, crown thee and all thy wishes, o Dorus up womee Dorus, up womee, up womee, up womee Dorus, teach me to climb the right way prithee

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: You must be muffled in the cloak, so now remember your instructions, make first your invocation to Apollo as I told you, which being done, employ your mind withal devotion to his deity, until you hear a voice call three times on you by your name, though you should think your father mother Pamela or myself talk to you answer not they are spirits that would delude.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Under three Mopsa's I'll not talk to 'em, I'll not be cozened

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hold there and you'll 'Be happy

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: I'll ask a King to my husband, and thou shalt be he

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Your invocation.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Into the great ears of Apollo
Now let my invocation hollow
O thou that lightest all the day
For some to work and some to play
By owl light now
Incline a gracious ear to me
thus ▪ muffled in thy wishing 〈◊〉
Singing whoop whoop whooe
And pardon this my subtlety
That I deceive the passers by
I in this bough
Do use the accents of that fowl
Because I would be thought an owl
With whoop whoop whoee

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: She has done her invocation

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Can she not hear us

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: She shall hear us, but I have taken order with her eyes and understanding too, she'll not believe us, thou lovely bird Madge owlet

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: That's a spirit in the voice of Dorus, but I'll not answer.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: See Dorus and Pamela both are here
Whilst old Dametas Miso, and their dear
Daughter are straggled forth, they both together
Are taking now their flight, and who knows whether

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: This is too plain

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: O cunning devils, but I'll not hear nor speak a syllable

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: If thou canst find a tongue to tell Dametas,
Make known unto his wisdom he is gulled
Take courage madam the way lies fair before us
And a barque already prepared cries come a w
Farewell owlet

div.stage: Exeunt Musidorus and Pamela Dametas sings within

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Whoop whoop whooe — heigh I hear another singing spirit in my father's voice, be't Apollo himself, under three Mopsa's I'll not speak

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: This is the tree, and here the earth is broken
The certain sign left by my trusty Dorus
The mouth of the rich treasure I salute thee
And kiss the hole from whence shall come my gold
Which being done blithely to work I fall
My hand is in the moonshine, and up goes all

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.l: Whoop whoop, whooe

sp.speaker: Dam,
sp.p: What's that; an owl, good mistress Margery I am busyArt thou poor and wouldst thou be advanced by wealth to dignity do not think it then unmeet to stoop with hands beneath thy feet 'tis not with hand over head to be found no no thou must stoop though thou holdest up thy poop and grabble for't in groundha what's this, my hand is in the honey pot I think, umh umh I do not like the softness, I did grope for harder stuff, if this be gold 'tis liquid, and yet too thick to be potable as they say, it has a kind of waif methinks if I have not lost a sense upon the sudden, I smell, call you this gold finding

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I have an extreme list now so I have saving your presence, devil would restore your sense

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
What's this, a written parchment this may be the inventory of all the treasure.
Who hath his hire hath well his labour placed
Earth thou didst seek, and store of earth thou hasthow's this

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Whoop whoop whooe

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: As sure as this is my own nose, I am stinkingly abused

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Ha ha ha,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Can Madge howlets laugh, that laugh was like my daughter Mopsa

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: There's one time, again again sweet Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: 'Tis her voice what makes she there, now the dread vengeance of my dear fatherly curse, light over th'wart thee thou awkward helding Mopsa

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: There's two times, Mopsa once more and 'tis Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Will you not answer in the devil's name Mopsa I say, o are you come

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Yes yes divine Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll unhood ye where's Pamela

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Thank your deity

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Speak now and tell me

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Answer my wishes as 'Thou art Phoebus, as thou art Apollo though in the likeness of the clown my father, grant me my wishes first, I ask a King to be my husband.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What talkest thou of a King; the King will hang thy father if Pamela be gone

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Let him be hanged I care not, but let Dorus be a King, and let him be my husband good Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: She's stark staring mad, hast thou forgotten thy father, where is thy wit

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I do not ask for wit, I tell thee, let me have a sufficient husband and let him be a King

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Thou shalt have thy bellyful of husbands

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: O that, that, that

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.l: I'll at you both thou ribald villain and thou harlot

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Miso my spouse fallen mad too
Thou wot not beat thy mother

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: O me

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I defy her and thee and thou beest not Apollo,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: O who has gulled us all, dear Miso, tender Mopsa hear me, before I open my mouth, art not thou Miso, and thou my daughter Mopsa, o we are all undone we are all undone

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Are not you god Apollo

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: No as ever I hope to see him or any of his fellows in the face again, I am mortal Dametas and I think thy father, I am sure I am by thy mother's side, where is Pamela all this while, who's at home.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As sure as you are my father and you my mother, there's nobody at home

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: She's gone, she's gone

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p:
Dorus and Pamela, or two fiends with their voices passed by whilst
I was in Apollo's tree

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Apollo's tree

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Cast off your wonder I am not such an ass, but I perceive we are gulled

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: So devil Dorus told me

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: O me they are gone, was this your care

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay then where was your own.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Fall not at odds bout that, but go with me
And help me to scape the gallow tree.

div.stage: Enter Gynoecia and Pyrocles, with a taper.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Did I not counterfeit an infirmity

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Rarely, how love will prompt his votary
The King suspects not what we purpose

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: 'Las poor man, how careful he seemed of my health
And counselled me to bed

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I smiled to see it

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: So soon as he is asleep expect me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Stay, oath sudden I ha' thought upon a way
Blessed blessed minute.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: What's the device

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: You sha'not go to bed

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Not I

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: God genius
I will not trust our work to fortune if
You should want cunning in your passions
Or he should wake unhappily and find
You absent, all were lost, to prevent this
You shall not come to me if there be danger
'Tis fit I be exposed I'll take your place
And disarray me for Basilius bed.
D'ye mark, muffled up for your supposed
Distemper, let me alone to counterfeit
Dullness, and when his senses are chained up
In sleep, I will come down tooth cave to you
But take my mantle if any of Dametas'
People meet you

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: I will visit but my closet
And follow thy instructions,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: If there be any stars are kind to love
This night shoot forth your golden heads, be thou
Bright moon propitious; on all eyes that would
Betray our flight, cast out a sullen mist
And hide thy silver cressent in a cloud,
But to our passage be a gentle goddess
And borrow of thy brother yet more light
The day may spare it, Musidorus is
sp.stage: Enter Gynoecia with a golden viol.
sp.l: Embarked already with his mistress,
If I obtain Philoclea's consent

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Zelmane now I am prepared

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Haste to the cave, expect,
Your servants visit

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: And my happiness

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: How rudely vice becomes us, here's a lady
Whom never fame yet blemished, now the example
Of Cupid's tyranny, love transforms us all
And fools our understandings, I pity her ▪
Now are Basilius thoughts in motion
And hurry him to the same licentiousness.
There is warm snow I see, he delays time.
In hope to find his Queen asleep, whose place
I must assume for once, love dwells upon
A cliff and all the ways to our enjoying
Are difficult and ragged,
But I forget, Basilius, I must
Compose me for his bed, I sha'not be
Much troubled, good old King he wishes me
Good rest I know, and secure dreams, o see
Philoclea what ways I come to thee

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: These sounds may charm her into slumbers sweetly
O steal into her, hang upon her heart,
Come fix your gentle raptures in her soul
That it may take delight to be o'ercome
And never wake the body, till Basilius
Return with happy conquest from Zelmane
Or if there be a leaden god of sleep.
Here let him shake his wings and then dispatch
A herald to the silent house of dreams
To bring one hither happier than the rest
To entertain my melancholy Queen; o Philoclea
Thy mother will excuse thee this night's duty
Do not disturb her, yet your voice and lute
Ith' next chamber may procure her sleep
That done without more ceremony go
To bed, so so my blood begins to move
She's fast, I hear her, and the music ceased,
Now to Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I'm troubled, and dare not go to bed
There's some thing whispers to my soul this will
Will be a fatal night, my mother is not well
I must needs see her — ha, the gods protect me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: If there were any treason meant against
Philoclea her prayers were vainly offered,
Since her own innocence is protection
As powerful as the gods, I bring no horror
To fright your blood, d'ye not know me lady
I was Zelmane,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Was

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I have been
So watched by your jealous mother

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: But I forget

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: To make fast the doors
If I could bar all the air out saving what
Your breath should draw, for should I live by that
You would not chide my care

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: If you cannot forgive me punish pray
This rudeness with my death; I prostrate to
Your feet my sword, and call you to my breast
To meet your anger, at this distance beg
I may behold you, but when you shall find
in the dissection of my heart, whose name
Hath filled it, and with what religion there
My thoughts adore your memory, too late
It may invite your tears, can fair Philoclea
Think I have a soul that dare be wicked to her?
Such looks would charm a ravisher, and throw
Ice through a satire's blood, but a man chaste
Already it draws up to the simplicity
And nature of an angel, o Philoclea
I am so far from being ill myself
In such a sensual way, that although time
And this fair opportunity might tempt
And excuse wanton heat, I should repent
Forget to, love yourself, if you but with
One thought so treacherous to your virgin honour
Should give consent to enjoy you, it hath snow
Upon my blood Philoclea, whose flowings
Are chaste as crystal: dare you trust me yet
To kiss your hand, my lips shall gently touch it
Nor will I leave a breath to stain the whiteness
Pray be not fearful.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Sin did never yet
Profane that voice.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: When it sounds lustfully
Your hate, a punishment next the wrath of heaven
Strike my heart dead — be pleased to rest a little
And if you dare vouch safe me to sit so near you ▪
I have much to tell you

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I know not what to say, where is my father
I had a mother too, this chamber they
Used to call their's

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: They are safe Philoclea,
Let not your cheek look pale, their absence wrought
For such a minute doth encourage me
To tell you now or never you must show
There dwells a pity in you, o look smooth
On him whose life and fortunes you may now
Advance or ruin ever, if you can
remember who I am, and what your virtue
Hath made me sister, think me worthy of
A life, let it begin from your consent
To love poor Pyrocles, 'tis in your power
To be no more a prisoner to this rude
And solitary dwelling, such a brightness
Is lost in caves, extend your arm and reach
A throne where seated with becoming greatness
You may disperse with moving of your eye
An influence beyond the stars, and quicken
A world that waits to be your creature

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Pyrocles
For so you call yourself, and such I dare
Believe you are, for falsehood cannot dwell
A neighbour to that tongue although I might
Demand with reason, and my duty first
What does concern my parents, such a truth
Shines in your language, and such innocence
In what you call affection, I must
Declare you have not placed one good thought here
Which is not answered with my heart, the fire
Which sparkled in your bosom long since leaped
Into my breast and there burns modestly
It would have spread into a greater flame
But still I curbed it with my tears, o Pyrocles
I would thou wert Zelmane again, and yet
I must confess I loved thee then, I know not
With what prophetic soul but I did wish
Often, thou were no man, or I no woman

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Thou wert the comfort of my sleeps

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And you
The object of my watches, when the night
Wanted a spell to cast me into slumber
Yet when the weight of my own thoughts grew heavy
For my tear dropping eyes, and drew these curtains
My dreams wert still of thee, forgive my blushes
And the imagination thou wert then
My harmless bed fellow

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I arrive too soon
At my desires, gently o gently drop
These joys into me, lest at once let fall
I sink beneath the tempest of my blessings
And you swell my heart too fast

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: If you be Pyrocles
You will rest satisfied with this confession
You only shall obtain my love

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Although my soul acknowledge this a blessing
Such as no service can reward enough
There remains something, something which your honour
May easily consent to in this absence
Of both your parents whom with several promises
Of my return, I have already sent
To'th cave where they in vain this night expect me
We must for this place, I have provided
For our conveyance to my father's kingdom
If after all these arguments of love
You dare trust Pyrocles to convey you thither,

sp.speaker: Phi,
sp.l: I dare give thee my life, but pardon me
This is not safe, thus seeking to assure.
You may untimely happen loose Philoclea
My duty binds me not to rob my parents,
Such a departure may undo their comfort
As you're a prince persuade me not commit
So unnatural a trespass, we'll expect
And satisfy our young desires till time
Mature our joy, I could content myself
To look on Pyrocles and think it happiness
Enough, or if my soul affect variety
Of pleasure every accent of thy voice
Shall court me with new rapture, and if these
Delights be narrow for us there is left
A modest kiss, whose every touch conveys
Our melting souls into each others lips,
Why should not you be pleased to look on me
To hear and sometimes kiss Philoclea
indeed you make me blush

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: What an eclipse
Hath that veil made, it was not night till now
Look if the stars have not withdrawn themselves
As they had waited on her richer brightness.
And missing of her eyes are stolen to bed,
What world of beauty is behind that cloud
But keep it still concealed, and let the creatures
When they shall miss day (For the same without
Thine eyes will glimmer like a petty taper)
Fear to be lost in darkness, and expect
No light to follow, but from those wide flames
Which heaven hath threatened to destroy the world,
When thou hast frighted us renew again
Our state and cure again the fainting universe
One look restores all — ha, Philoclea.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: There's something that sits heavy on my forehead
I know you cannot but be noble, pray
A little sleep, if I exceed three minutes
Prithee wake me

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Ha, I do not like
Her senses should be snatched away so strangely
'Tis an ill omen, I should trespass much
'Gainst manners, to disturb her, beside she
Did make it her request whose will is sacred,
Then gently may she sleep, and yet if she
Draw out this slumber to any length my hopes
Are blasted, if I lose this opportunity
Of flight, no hope hereafter can relieve us
We are both undone, she sleeps still, I was not
Quick enough to persuade her resolution
So necessary, yet look up Philoclea,
No, then enjoy thy dream, and let us try
The kindness of our fate, pity a harsh
Sound should disturb thy soft repose, I would
But dare not steal a kiss for fear to wake her,
And yet my loud voice may be more offensive
Our souls are knit I see into one love
then 'tis but reason they should exercise
Both the same act, why do not I sleep too
The mist is fallen already, if I but dream of her
My slumbers shall be happy

div.stage: Enter Dametas as from a vault.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: There be more ways to the wood than one, she may be in her sister's chamber, I may thank my acquaintance with the buttery and a trap door for this passage; she has shut me out of doors of all: umh a sword I had rather it were Pamela naked, I durst undertake to handle her with less fear; umh Philoclea; 'tis she and this is-no — this is not Pamela, she was a woman, unless she be crept into breeches since I left her, no 'tis a man, here is no tarrying for me; and he were not soundly asleep , my smell were enough to wake him; — treason treason

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Ha, what voice is that, who cries out treason?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Pyrocles what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Nothing

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Hark, is't not treason, my sword, my sword
Is gone, we are betrayed, some thief has been
Within the chamber, yet the doors are safe ▪ ha
Let's see, search everywhere , alas Philoclea
If now I must be ravished from thee, how
Can there be charity enough on earth
To pity me, they die but once who still
Despair of bliss; but the fares twice destroy
A lover whom they kill so near his joy.

div.head: Actus quartus.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come my bloods since there is no hope of our pardons let us be honest outlaws one to another, and do all the mischief we can, we are masters of the woods, and we will domineer like lords of the soil; I say we will live, we will eat and we will drink.

sp.l: Would I were at my forge again

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Arcadia shall be thy anvil smith; and thou mayst live to beat
Great men to dust
Some of them are so rotten they will save us a labour

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Be resolute and strike the iron while it is hot, where is the little miller

sp.l: Thumb the miller is cut off

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Who can help it, be not crest fallen, but show yourselves cocks of the game, we'll make the state send for us home, and agree to our own conditions, let us therefore play the thieves manfully
And so be hanged honourably

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Hang hang ng, we defy the laws and we will execute when we list in our own quarters we will rob man woman and child
Do you fight with the men, and let me alone with the women.
And Thumb had he been alive he had been a fit match for the children
A prize a captain, I see a gentleman and a lady strike into a grove hard by, their horses are for their better behaviour, already bound to a tree, follow me and I'll conduct

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Without noise or tumult let's steal upon them

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: This grove is all one bower, nature herself
Must be delighted to dwell here, the sun
Can shoot no beam upon us through this arbour
Though he does rage abroad

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: The heat betrays
The sun is angry madam to see you
Whose brightness takes all wonder from his shine
And leave him a pale star.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: You compliment.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Are you not weary madam

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I shall never
In thy society, yet we may rest
A little in this shade, o m 〈…〉
He should be enemy to virtue now
to cherish one suspectful thought of thee
Some wild licentious prince had now 〈◊〉 me
And careless of his own ruined my honour.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: It were not simple theft but sacrilege
To rob you of one peaceful thought, if any
Service already have obtained so much
Trust I am so familiar with mine own
Desires, that hereafter I'll deserve to keep
Your fair opinion of me, lust could never
Intrude himself a guest here, I should not
Love mine own eyes, had they been but tempted
To see an unchaste picture with delight

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What's that behind the trees?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Nothing, the birds are dancing on the leaves
Called hither by the music of your tongue
Those that are silent do but listen to
Your voice to mend their singing

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Still methinks I hear another noise

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: It is your fear

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: There's some thing whispers

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Shall I tell Pamela

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Pray if you can

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: It is the wind that would
Steal through the boughs to give you more refreshing
Whom the trees envy, I do hear it murmur
To be kept from your lips which it would kiss
And mixing with your breath catch odours thence
Enough to sweeten all the wood, there can
No other danger enter here

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: We are betrayed help

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Ha, villains, y'ad better lay violent hands
Upon your mothers

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Let your courage cool, and hear us you were best
If you do love this gentlewoman's life.
Put up your tool, d'ye see this bodkin sir
With it, I'll punch her heart, if you but offer
A blow at any of my train, I'll do't
As I am true rebel and for the more security
deliver up your whinyard to our uses
Or I'll make an eyelet-hole presently

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Do not resign your sword but use it.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hold hear me

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Let us both die with honour, do not give
Your strength and trust to th' mercy of those slaves
In humane villains to us

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: But thy life, — as you are men but hear me

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Drop your steel quickly, or

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Alas she is my wife
Your wife, if you love her be not troublesome I tell you again

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Pamela bids thee fight, fear not for me
If I die I shall not be dishonoured
And thou shalt take a brave revenge on them,
Pity not me to lose us both, we'll meet
Again in death and love eternally

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: My soul's divided, shall I venture her?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I'll stay no longer

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Hold and take my sword
But swear by some religion you will use
No violence to her
We swear

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: So first and foremost throw his sword out of the way, we have no use on't, secondly bind him to a tree

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Set her at liberty
And use what cruelty you please on me
Kill me, and I'll forgive you.
Forgive us, heaven forgive thee, say thy prayers

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I see there's pity in you, if your wants
Council you to this sinful trade, we both
Will freely give our wealth, we have some jewels
Of value to redeem you all, and make
You rich if you dare first be so in goodness
And exercise no tyranny upon
Our bodies, what a misery it is
Such spirits as you are should not have fortunes
High as your thoughts, when every dunghill fellow
surfeits with honours and estates, and vomits
In taverns what would keep your families,
But 'tis the time's disease, when merit thus
Disgraced and unrewarded by the state
Makes subjects desperate
He says true

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I prithee take my clothes, would they were rich
And worth your pillage, and will serve me
Alas good gentleman, let e'en strip him

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: None dare to take a skirt

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Perhaps for some offences you are banished
Your houses and estates
For nothing but being drunk
And offering to kill the King
He will not live amongst us as a good King ought.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Alas good men, I do presume you, would not have killed the King in any malice to him
I love the King withal my heart, and a pox take him that does not, would he would but pardon us

sp.l: There's no hope now, we have submitted ourselves too often

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Yet let him hear well of you, and though
Necessity compel you to be thieves,
Be honest thieves and ravish nobody .
And this report arriving at his ears
It inclines him to have pity on you
And call you to his favour

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Unhand the gentlewoman, he that offers her
But a wry look had better eat my sword
Or my scabbard though it have been pissed in
Faith captain he hath given us good council let us deal
Honestly, if we take away but all they have they will
Have more cause to speak well of us

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Unbind the malefactor
Shall I give him his sword?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: His sword thou ignorant thief no so he may chance to ask us again for his jewels; take thy Penelope sweet tongued Ulysses; and on the next back smother her in kisses — farewell

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: O, my Pamela.

sp.p: Captain captain come backe he calls her Pamela that should be the King's daughter,

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How, umh; now I look better on her I have seen that face in a mask before now

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: We are lost again

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: I am the same Pamela
What ha' we done, here are all your jewels not a stone diminished

sp.l: If there be let me be gelded

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I easily forgive all and will be
So far from a complaint that I'll plead for
Your pardons to my father, and he shall not
Be able to deny me
sp.p: Omnes a pardon, a pardon, if it please your highness we'll go back with you

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Not with me

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: As we are true men and thieves madam

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: We are undone again

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: At our return I'll join with her

sp.p: Return, why whether are you going so far from the lodge this is the way to the sea

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Umh, I guest treason, are not you an't shall please your ladyship running away with this gentleman

sp.l: He said she was his wife
I do not like him

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Lay hands on him again, well thought upon you shall justify yourselves before the King

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Dare you go to the King without a pardon
'Tis the only way to procure one

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Rather go with us, and, as I am —
What are you

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: I am — I know not

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: We'll teach you to know yourself; away with 'em we are all made

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Villains and rebels.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Zelmane has abused me

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Chide not her
'Twas mine own plot to try your constancy.
Death cease upon Zelmane for his coming
But I will be revenged, when did I fall
From my high birth; in what lascivious action
Lost I my fame, that this Basilius
Should wrong his own Gynoecia

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I am ashamed, I prithee chide no more.
She gave me sure some philtre to betray
My blood to this dishonour.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Though your lust
Missed the enjoying him for whom your heart
Grew wanton, yet the sin cannot be purged
They are adulterate sheets, and those embraces
Which locked mine arms thy guilt, not one warm kiss
But was intended for Zelmane's lips
O my fate

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Prithee forgive

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: The silence which I used
I wished might save my modesty a language
To accuse you now; indeed you have done ill
Touse me thus

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: My love to thee hereafter
Shall redeem all, wound me no more I prithee

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: If vice have so possessed you that my bed
Is now grown hateful, make me not the scorn
Of all your kingdom, send me home again
To Argos to wear out my life in weeping
My lord has quite forsaken me

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Not for
The crowns of Greece, and all the world dear dearest
Gynoecia pardon thou hast saved mine honour
Destroy me not again, on what a rock
(Had not thy goodness rescued me) had I
Been ever ship wracked, take me to thy love,
A sad man for my fault, never, o never
Shall such unworthy thoughts corrupt my heart
To leave a chaste wife

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: I do freely pardon this error

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Then I am straight again

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: But Zelmane shall account
Dear for this unless he satisfy
My furious blood, new welcome to my bosom

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: A cup of wine would crown our reconcilement
As I remember in the cave I saw
A golden bottle

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Your majesty may taste on't, but I meant it
A draught for false Zelmane, it being virtual
To increase affection, to me a gift
My mother's love bestowed when I was married
To Basilius if ever he grew cold
To quicken his desires, I never yet
Made trial

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: It is the gods
Nepenthe, or a drink more precious
I prithee give't a name, and if my kingdom
Afford th'ingredients let me taste it often;
Ha Gynoecia where am I?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Here my lord

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: I think I am deceived, my tongue o'th' sudden draws backward; and my limbs grow very feeble ha, oh-farwell.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: My lord, my lord, Basilius, o he's dead
If he be poisoned I have made fair work
Dear husband, then for ever mourn Gynoecia
The gods have punished thy lascivious heat
With hasty justice, hath my care so long
Almost religiously preserved this drink
To kill thus in a minute; o my soul
Doth feel a scorpion, and my lust appears
Circled with thousand furies
