sp.speaker: Shepherd
sp.l: Treason treason

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Do set out your throat here; and let me alone to roar treason in the ears of my lord Philonax — I should ha' been the town crier

sp.speaker: Shepherd
sp.l: Make haste.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: O yes treason,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: When you have spent your voices, let your eyes
speak a more killing language

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Ha, the Queen, madam Pamela, is gone

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: No matter for Pamela, look here shepherds
Here lies the King

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: No matter for Pamela? I am glad of that
Is his majesty asleep

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Never to awake, he's dead poisoned by this viol

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: O base viol, why here is more treason than we looked for, this is admirable, did he die against his will, or was he killed a natural death let us sit upon him

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: For bear, I can direct you to the murderer
Look here you shepherds, it was I that killed him

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: You, your majesty is very merry

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Will you not trust me

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Yes for more than I am worth, but if you killed him yourself, your majesty must pardon me for that, I have nothing to say to you but, treason treason;

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Yet fly Gynoecia and save thy life,
Betray not thine own, life; why do I talk
Of safety, can there be in all the world
A consort, when my honour and Basilius
Have both forsaken me

div.stage: Enter Philonax and Dametas with a guard.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.p: Pamela gone, how does the King take it

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The King, would he could take it any way, good gentleman he's in a pitiful taking himself

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.p: What sales the screech-owl

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The truth is, he is sent of an errand to Erebus he's dead, and for my lady Philoclea, whom I suspect

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.p: Ha

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And you make haste you may take her napping, there is a thing in the likeness of a man with her, whom very valiantly I disarmed, and brought away his naked weapon

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.p: What traitor? didst disarm him?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Did I and there had been twenty of 'em I would not have cared a rush though they had been as valiant as Hector, had I not treason a'my side so soon as I came in

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.p: Thou dost amaze me what said he?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Never a word, my friend quoth to his sword

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Idiot didst speak to his sword?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Why he was fast asleep my lord,
And never so much as dreamt of me

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.p: asleep , we lose time go you along with Dametas, seize upon that traitor, o I am rent with sorrow

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Come my masters be not afraid as long as I have a sword
You shall go before, and follow my example there's the
King my lord

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Madam

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: O Philonax

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Be comforted

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: You sha'not need to mock me, when you know
By whom he died thou wilt call in thy charity
And curse me, it was I that poisoned him,

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Good madam speak that I may understand,
You poisoned him? he was Basilius
Your husband and your King, it cannot be
You are the Queen his wife

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: His murderer
The horror of my sin dwells round about me
I need no more accusers than my conscience.
Do with me what you please, the wicked reasons
That moved me to it you shall know hereafter

sp.speaker: Philon,
sp.l: Bless me eternity, I'll not believe
That any woman after this can love
Her husband, o my lord, merciless woman
For here all other titles lost away
With her, see her lodged within the castle.

div.stage: Enter Dametas and a guard with Philoclea and Pyrocles at one door, at the other enter the rebels with Musidorus and Pamela.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Here they are my lord

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: New uproars.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: My charge, 'tis Pamela, my lord Philonax 'tis Pamela Philon, Pamela and Philoclea

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p:
Yes my lord we suspected they were running away
together and therefore in hope of his majesty's pardon

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.l: Musidorus and thy sister under guard?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Pyrocles and Philoclea prisoners too?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.p: Look here unnatural children, for I cannot pronounce you innocent, this circumstance betrays your guilt, see where your King and father lies a cold pattern for a tomb

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Dead?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O we are miserable

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Basilus dead?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Slain

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: He was murdered, and you are accessaries
Sure I have seen your face; were not you called
Zelmane the Amazon?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I was.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Disguises, injurious villain
Profaner of all hospitable laws

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I am not loose to answer thee

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: And this was my man Dorus my lord, a ha have I found you sirrah, you sent me abroad to be a gold-finder.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: You have done service worthy all your pardons.
Now in my rage I could prevent the law
And sacrifice their treacherous bloods myself
To this reverend hearse.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: You are transported Philonax
But that I have compassion for the death
Of that good King I could laugh at thee.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Hence, load them with irons, ladies you must both
Be patient to be confined until
You clear yourselves.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What saucy fellow's that?
Meant you me Philonax, unhand those prisoners

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Away with 'em I command

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Yet stay and hear me
As you did love Basilius hear his daughter,
This insolence doth interupt the tears
Due to my dear dead father, and enforces
Me, since he thus forgets, to declare to you
With confidence who I am, I am Pamela
The eldest daughter of Basilius
Your Queen if I mistake not, since my father
is dead, to whose memory these pious drops
Fall as the tribute of my grief, who then
Shall be obeyed, he that was trusted with
My father's power, which in his death is cancelled
Or I your natural Princess?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Umh, my charge speaks to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Have you found so much sweetness in the reign
You borrowed of my father, that you would
Usurp now he is dead? I have not signed
Any commission for your office, how
Dare you then in my presence command any
To prison, nay like a bold insolent traitor
Talk of confining me? we are merciful
To let you keep your proud head on.

sp.speaker: Rebel
sp.l: What will be come of us?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: You shall have clean halters.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: But in the justice to my royal father,
Snatched hence untimely from us, since you attempt
To charge them with his death, we give you space
To live and to accuse them, they shall be
Our prisoners, ith' mean time 'twill become
Your person to go home and study how
To play the advocate when you are called
By us, and the grave laws, you are dismissed.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: I am astonished, do you not wonder with me
To hear the daughter of our late good King
Lost to her filial piety, this comes.
Too near apracide Pamela. Countrymen
It is apparent they have all conspired
The death of the old King, methinks I hear
His groans confirm it, if you suffer such
A treason pass Arcadia will become
The scorn of all the world, nor ever shall
Any good prince; trust his life amongst you,
For my ambition, all the angels know
How tedious the hours have been, since I
Was forced to take this kingdom's weight upon me.
But let not ceremony to the daughter.
Whose title I dispute not shame our duties
To him that was her father and our master.
Poisoned, yes poisoned by those men that have
No names, and will betray in our remissness
The honour of these ladies and our country
As they have done his precious life already,
As you are good men let them be arraigned
If they be innocent their goodness will
Protect them, but if guilty let them die
Like slaves unpitied.

sp.speaker: Rebel
sp.l: A Philonax, a Philonax

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Dare ye all be traitors then?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: This your great love revives me, then convey
All to the castle, but command these two
As traitors to be made safe, the ladies shall
Be under mild restraint.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Villains

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: You lives shall dear answer this.
We must obey the tyrant, were our hands
At liberty, and armed with our good swords
We should not off so tamely.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Come away traitors.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Well remembered you.
Are not to be discharged, lodge him safe too.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Who I, he does not mean me, my lord these fellows.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Take him a way, a traitor with the rest,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Away away

sp.speaker: Rebel
sp.l: So you must sir

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Would I might never see my wife and children in my right wits, if I be a traitor that's enough my lord, they'll carry me away too.

sp.speaker: Rebel
sp.l: D'ye remember a clean halter? come on sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: King Evarchus sayest?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: He has but a small train my lord.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Alas he comes too late to visit, but
Most seasonable to be a judge in this
Great cause, take gently up that royal body
Whose souls a star already, all that we
Can pay is justice to his memory.

div.head: Actus quintus.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Good master jailor you might be so courteous in your office to let us see these gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Madam I dare not,

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: 'Tis well you dare obey King Philonax and be a rebel to me, the time may come you will repent.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Confident that you will keep your princely words not to interupt or change any discourse with 'em, I have brought you where you may though at some distance hear 'em, they are preparing for music, 'tis all I dare consent to, neither durst I tell them you should be with in reach of their voices

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Well sir we are content

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: We'll speak with 'em but in your hearing,

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Do not entreat him sister, pray have a special remembrance to let 'em want air and necessaries, you'll 'Forfeit your place if you make conscience to be over honest to 'em.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I am sorry madam you accuse my nature
Which never yet was observed cruel, I
Would be as just to your commands.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: So it seems

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Were these misfortunes over

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Good sir no tedious excuses nor apology but proceed you and your great master Philonax, and he will make you his treasurer, or trust you with his great seal, you cannot choose but be an excellent keeper.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What will become of us?

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Nay what will become a'th' princes, there's my fear, would they were free again, and had but their good swords to second their innocence, I am mad to think what a condition we are fallen to, prithee Philoclea shed some tears for me, if I weep now it must be for anger that we cannot help 'em, but let the graybeards look to't, for if they suffer, unless they send me of an errand after them, not a head that nodded to their sentence, shall know where to find shoulders to support 'em

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Alas sister I want drops for my own grief
My father's death,

sp.speaker: Pum.
sp.l: My father, that that hath opened
The spring again

sp.speaker: Ph●.
sp.l: And although guilty of his blood, for so
they say our mother hath confessed herself
I must in duty weep for her.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: My mother
That word strikes double sorrow, and doth call
A flood to drown my eyes, shall we not see her?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She could not kill him sure, did ever grief
So soon make such a pair of orphans, our
Fortunes are so strange and thick, posterity
Will think our story fiction, and yet
It seems they're not so great to break our hearts
A'th sudden, I would willingly die too
But I remember Pyrocles

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: And I my dear loved Musidorus, at which name
My tears dry up, and black revenge prepares
Thy throne within my blood, but Simpathus

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Madam

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Are not the princes sent for yet?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Not yet

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I prithee tell me how they look; what say they to thee?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Do they name us?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: It hath been all their question, how both their
Princely mistresses do fare, for so
They call you ladies, when I answer well
Their joy shoots up in prayers that you may still
Continue safe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Do they not rail sometimes and curse?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I never heard 'em

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Canst thou be such a fool then to believe
They are murderers?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I do not believe they are

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Do not if thou dar'st be a knave, and try if the devil will bear you out in't, we must not see 'em

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.l: Alas madam

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: Nor speak to our mother,

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I am commanded

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Thou shalt not deny us a little discourse with Dametas my old governor since we have no other company.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You shall

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: His presence could be never more unwelcome
Beside his follies will but ill agree
With our affliction

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: They cannot hurt
Us sister I have a breast as deeply charged
As thine although I flatter it, 'tis no sin
To enable us for bearing — how d'ye governor?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: How d'ye madam, 'E'en as you see, as ill as this iron age can make a man

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: What will they do with thee?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: They cannot use me worse than they have; for I am hanged in chains already, I have had three whippings into the bargain to, if they hold such a hand over me long, I shall never be able to sleep in a whole skin.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Had you any hand in my father's death?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hand, I was so far from having any hand, that I had not so much as a finger in't, no your mother poisoned him with a base viol.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O misery!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But madam, I did not think you had been so dishonest, and you had meant to run away with anybody I thought you would have told me so, but I see a woman and a wet eel have both slippery tails.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: You ran away from me.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Who I run? I was never so good a foot man in my life, alas I was told by that rascal Dorus where a great deal of gold was buried, and I went simply with a resolution after I came home to build half a dozen churches, but now I hear say there is a gallows built to my hands, and I must hang ding dung like a bell in the wooden steeple.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Speak well of Dorus sirrah, you had more need to pray for him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Heaven convert him then, and though he live when I am dead he may be rotten as soon as I

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Who sent you sirrah to my chamber?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Sent me, the devil; and I ha' thrived accordingly, would my wife had broke her neck when I took you together.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.p: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Or my daughter, or you or anybody to save the loose of my own sweet madam speak a good word for me, and I'll — speak another for you, my evidence will be heard, and I care not what I swear; 'tis not for the King he's dead, I look every minute for a voice to call me to the sessions.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hey there 'tis already, as ever you hope to be married while your maiden heads are sweet; save me from the gallows, for if I be once hanged I shall never be my own man again.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: They are very hasty to arraign 'em, Pyrocles
there's nothing left me now but prayers for thee
With which I'll weary heaven or tire myself
For thy success.

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: I would do so but I
Fear my revenge will kill my charity.

div.stage: Exeunt, enter Evarchus, Philonax and Slmpathus, the bear.

sp.speaker: Euax.
sp.l: My lord your sorrow and not my ambition
Hath made me judge today, therefore attend
The proof of your election, I came
With purpose of a visit to your master
But now salute his hearse, and wear a title
Of your protector, in which name I gave command
The prisoners should be sent for.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: 'Tis done, and they are ready;

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: My lord my part today is to accuse
And not side in compassion.

div.stage: Enter Gynoecia, Mufidorus, Pyrocles and Dametas guarded: a bar set out.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: That the Queen?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Yes, my lord

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: She shows a much dejected lady.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Has she not cause?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Those the pretended princes?
Of comely presence both, what's he?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Dametas to whose trust the King gave up
Pamela his eldest daughter.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Where is she?

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Accompanied with her sister in the castle
Their presence might occasion some tumult,
Nor do the Arcadian laws allow proceeding
Against the next of blood, as they permit not
She should determine anything herself
Till years or marriage enable her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will forgive thee Philonax for more malice than thou hast brought against my life, for being so honest to Pamela,

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Sir I look not for your thanks

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: As you are honourable, I beseech you
I'th name of sacred justice, ere you further
Proceed against our facts declare what you
Determine of Philolea, who is all innocence
And most unjustly suffers, though in thought
you doubt their virgin honour

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: She must become a recluse
And all her life with strict profession
Of chastity repair her blemished honour.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: A vestal?
Not if I live, yet if I die it carries
This comfort none hereafter shall enjoy
The fair Philoclea.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Now to the Queen

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Madam stand to the bar.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: My bar indeed which I have laid myself
To bring my honour to a fall and ruin
O my dear lord my tears do now embalm thee,
My blood shall quickly follow.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: As you are just
Let not her sorrow tempt you to forget
What sin she hath committed, I want words
To express the horror of the deed which will
Throw shame on all her sex.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Stay Philonax shalt have.
What thou desirest, I have been a judge already
Upon myself and do not desire life,
That am condemned by my own killing sentence
I do again confess I was the murderer
Of your and my lord, robbed Arcadia and
My children of a father, ay, none but I
Poisoned Basilius

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Palladius dost hear?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Unfortunate lady,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: And what could Philonax say more against me?
There remains only to obey your judgement
Which cannot come in any shape of death
Too horrid for my sin I'm very weary
Of this bad world, be just and take a life
From me that else will groan itself away
And mock your justice.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: You hear my lord?

sp.speaker: Evar.
sp.l: And thus proceed to sentence
Having confessed, to spare your proof how much
She hath offended, an example to all times
We censure thus, she shall presently
Be carried to prison where she may
Have food but only to sustain her life
Until her husband's burial, with whom
in the same vault she shall be closed alive
To keep his body company from which
Her cruelty divorced his soul,

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: You're just.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: My heart weeps for her

sp.speaker: Mus,
sp.l: 'Tis a severe sentence.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: Who binds my hands? Basilius I come
To be a living guest in thy sad tomb.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: The others to the bar

sp.speaker: Eva.
sp.l: What are their names?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: Daiphantas of Licia mine

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Mine Palladius of Iberia.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: We do not dispute their titles here, they are
Private persons, you may proceed.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: I shall, and with as much brevity

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Choose whom you'll first accuse.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Then first this Daiphantas, this Zelmane
This what you will, for he hath yet no name
Nor shape that we can trust to, having knowledge
Of our late master's solitary life,
Came not without a purpose of this treachery
And by the cunning of Gynoecia
Ith' habit of a woman was received
As an unsuspected guest, enjoyed the freedom,
Of those whom the King placed nearest his bosom,
His children not more dear, treason thus fortified
They soon conspired the death of this good King,
A cave this gentlewoman's, lodging was
The fatal scene where the unhappy Queen
By his direction forced his dear life from him
I omit what lustful motive prompted her
That with more licence she might twine with this
Hermaphrodite, and that they had appointed
Where they might meet when this black deed was done,
But heaven was merciful and prevented her
Flight by the happy coming in of shepherds
In the mean time transported with the confidence
Of her performance, that he might not leave
any revenger of this hateful murder
He hastily makes up to Philoclea's chamber,
Whereby the mingling (What he could) her shame
With his offence, he easily might enforce
Her to be accessary to her father's death,
And under her protection, and her sisters
('gainst whom they knew we were not to rebel)
Seize with one gripe the state, but heaven preserved
All by the unexpected coming up
Of this Dametas.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Yes heaven and I preserved all.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Who sought then for Pamela
Which the other princely thief had stolen away,
And finding these, I mean Philoclea
And this young man together, found occasion
To enclose the ravisher till by command
They were apprehended: thus you have in short
His wicked story, and what punishment
Will not be thought a mercy to that monster
That kills a King, dishonoureth a Queen,
And violates the daughter?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: In things promoted with such cunning mixture
'Tis hard to shape a square and direct answer.
My accusers sordid and malicious railing
More grievous to my tender sense of honour
Then death can be, I forget him
A thing beneath my anger and armed with
My own simplicity doubt not to assure
How much my cause is injured, know grave judge
This prince and I drawn hither by the fame
Of the rare beauties in Basilius daughters
Knowing that with their parents they lived here
Secluded from the world, where no access
In our own persons was to be expected,
Put on these forms as soonest might conduce
To make our loves known: this Palladius
Became so fortunate that his princely mistress
Consented to forsake, and trust his conduct
to a happier kingdom: my fortune
Was not so happy, for I did not cherish
A greater flame, yet modest, of Philoclea
Then her weak father in my sex deceived
Retained of me, that tired with his solicits
I had no time to perfect my desires
With his fair daughter,
Till under colour of some devotions
I made a cave my lodging to invite
Basilius thither, with full hope to enjoy me,
But this revealing to the Queen, she took
My place to make the old King see his follies.
In the mean time I must confess I went
To bright Philoclea's chamber hoping to
Win her by all the charms of noble love
To leave Arcadia; but she unhappily
Obeying her own genius gave no
Consent, when in the midst of my security
I know not by what means I was made prisoner.
And here's the thread to guide through this labyrinth,
Methinks your man of mighty tongue should blush
To have spent his rage so poorly.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: What ic all this to the death of the old King?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: By all the gods I am innocent
The Queen hath absolved me, as for Philoclea
If you will call't a crime in that I loved her
I am and shall be guilty, but had never
A thought so rude to force her unstained chastity:
Or if the honour of this excellent lady
Suffer it'h blind opinion of the world
Our marriage not my death may cure all wounds
Malice can fasten on her name.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: O impudence.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: If this be all you have to say proceed
To his confederate.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: The imagination how miserable
These jugglers would have made us and our country
If their disguise had prospered, strikes a terror
through all my faculties, my tongue's enfeebled.
Therefore to omit his practice in the murder
Which you may easily collect by circumstance
This is enough to call him a foul traitor
He did attempt to steal a way out Princess
The hope and treasure of Arcadia
And taken in the fact dares not deny it,
Had he no other cry me to answer for
This pulls severe death on him, and to insist
Upon offences of so foul a nature
Were to distrust your wisdom or your justice.
Thou to their shame of mankind speak to this.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Not for thy sake who in this misery
Hast only merited to be my scorn
But for the truth I answer, pardon sir
If passion make me not remember language
That should become this place, this ill tongued man
That with such vehemence accuseth thus
Is himself guilty.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Of a more hateful vice, ingratitude.
Is this the payment for our services
Which once thy tongue acknowledged had deserved
Statues to the eternal memory
Of the preservers of your King and country?
Is all the valour of this young man cancelled
When rebels had advanced their daring swords
High as the throat of your old King, his wife
And trembling daughters, is the time forgotten
When wild beasts had prepared their riotous maws
To bury the dear pledges of your kingdom?
O where had been my treason or his rape
Had they been then devoured? the ground has not
Drunk up the blood so perfectly, but there
Remains a colour to teach impious men
To blush for their ingratitude, have we
Been careless of our lives to preserve
The King when danger threatened horror to him
and can a temperate man imagine we
Should be his murderers, we had not saved
To be ourselves the hangmen? but I'm charged
For stealing of your Princess, can your breathes
Acknowledge her your sovereign, and allow
No faith to what she says, you have degraded
My blood from honour, and unless you make me
Less than her subject I was bound to obey
When she commanded I should wait upon her,
But you'll object I counselled her, I did
And justify the act, she was confined
Too narrowly, and I durst lead her to
A throne above the majesty her birth
Can challenge in Arcadia, love whose force
The gods have not resisted may plead for me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Though it want method 'tis enough to vindicate
My honour from his base aspersion.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: To him you call Dametas

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Not guilty my lord, as I hope to be saved not guilty.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Neglect of the great charge with which the King
Our master trusted him sums up his fault.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: I was made a gold-finder, I desire justice for him and
Mercy for myself.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Silence.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I have heard you with attention, and whereas
To the King's death (The unhappy cause of this
Assembly) you have answered with denial
Which you think fortified by the Queen's
Self's only accusation, I must tell you
It frees you not, for though no manifest proofs
Yet circumstances well examined make you
The accidental causes of his murder.
For the other part of your offence I find not
You have denied your guilt, but only use
Qualification and excuse; your services
In themselves high and honourable, allow you
No privilege to offend, but give your black, faults
a black die; then justly weighing your offence, you meet
In equal guilt, for though you first conveyed
Away Pamela, his intention was
Early as yours, and by the rules of justice
The will stands for the act, both ravished
Although not of the ladies from themselves
Yet from their parents and their country, which
By all the Grecian laws is paid with death.
Thus then I must pronounce Daiphantas shall
Be thrown from some high tower to mere his death,
Palladius lose his head before sunset
The executioner shall be Dametas
Which office of the common hangman he
Shall for his whole life execute, a punishment
For his neglect of duty.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Must I be hangman? o brave, heaven preserve your lordship, I shall quickly learn the trade, and if ever any of your honours have occasion to use me, I will owe you a good turn, and in token I have been bound to you the knot of my dutiful affection, shall tell a tale in your ear you shall thank me when you are hanged, come your ways, but I beseech your lordship, I may be allowed a man some times I would be loath to hang or to behead myself, my wife or my own kindred, but if it happen there be more work than he can turn his hands to, I will not stick with him to hang myself, provide you malefactors and let me alone for halters.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.l: Hold stay the prisoners my lord protector

sp.speaker: Calo.
sp.l: O my lord

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: My servant Calodoulus by thy duty
Reveal us not.

sp.speaker: Calo.
sp.l: Let me rather be dumb eternally
Than two such princes be lost by my silence.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My son and nephew are they living?

sp.speaker: Calo.
sp.l: Your own Pyrocles and his princely nephew,

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.l: Ask your father blessing, unhand 'em rascals.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: The two most famous princes in the world.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: 'Tis Evarchus thy father Pyrocles, my uncle King of Macedon, all ye gods, my heart is ecstasied with joy.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: My father

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My blessing and my tears you both divide.
Witness with me, ye immortal powers this day
I have done nothing, but what justice and
Your native laws require, without the knowledge
How near they were to my own blood, but since
They are proved my son and nephew
Endowed by nature richly, and how meriting
The fame and love of all the world before
This accident, I leave to your own thoughts,
Besides these two I have no joys of life.

sp.speaker: Cala.
sp.l: Excellent Evarchus; why did you change your names?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: To prevent the dishonour of our blood
If we had suffered

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: But I have judged already and if right
I have not wronged, unless the name
Of child have power to alter sacred justice
You both must die, though when I speak your death
It creeps upon my heart.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: We dream, is this thy father Pyrocles?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Away with 'em.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: 'Tis most tyrannical he is thy son.
Thou wot not be a murderer of thy own?
Make not thy name hated of all the world
When it shall say hereafter Pyrocles
Had no fault in him but he was thy son.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: For me I am his own and being so
Disposed of by his justice; to whom rather
I hoped to have been a comfort then a shame
I kiss my sentence; but you cannot place
Your kinsman in the sacrifice his mother
And country plead a title he is theirs
O save my princely cousin

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Sure I sha'not live
Long after them, and gentlemen if I die
Before I leave Arcadia let my ashes
Mingle with theirs:

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: O o o

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: My lord, gentlemen, there's something stirs and groans come back.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Basilius alive, assist him Philonax.
He breathes, what 〈◊〉 of joy run through me?
Send for Gynoecia and his daughters.

sp.speaker: Bas
sp.l: Why am I supported thus like a dead man?
What are you?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Evarchus your old friend.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: I ha' seen that face before, 'tis like sweet Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My son

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: But was a counterfeit Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Wonders, and you?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My nephew, prince of Thessaly

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Though 〈◊〉 your servant Dorus

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Very strange; Gynoecia

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: My dear lord returned
A thousand kisses welcome him to life
Which I was weary of in thy loss.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: My daughters

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: O my father

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Are you Philonax?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Your trusty servant

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: The oracle is accomplished.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: You amaze me, let me collect

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: O my sweet Pyrocles

sp.speaker: Pam.
sp.l: We shall not be sepulchred I hope again

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.l: I am your servant ever

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Divinest mistress

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Your souls I see are married
Let me present these princes to be your sons

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: Is this real?

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.l: 'Tis dangerous to expect the story.
I feared the drink, but it may be his virtue
To increase his love to me, I'll tell you more within sir.

sp.speaker: Philon.
sp.l: Let me obtain your pardons

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: To his chamber 〈◊〉 him gently

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.l: All is strange.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.l: Never was day so full of happy change

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
